user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileOpenCheck:
```c
int32 OS_FileOpenCheck(const char *Filename)
{
    int32                        return_code;
    OS_object_iter_t             iter;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Filename);

    return_code = OS_ERROR;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, iter.token);
        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID && (strcmp(stream->stream_name, Filename) == 0))
        {
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_FileOpenCheck:
int32 OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(osal_objtype_t objtype, OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectFilterActive, NULL, objtype, iter);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The loop uses the boolean variable 'got_next' as the controlling expression (!got_next). 'got_next' is a local variable initialized to false and is set to true inside the loop when a matching record is found. Therefore the controlling expression is not invariant (it changes during execution). The loop can also be exited via the 'break' when iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit. No MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 violation is present.
